DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Most grain and soybean futures prices fell slightly Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as badly needed precipitation fell in U.S. winter wheat region and the Brazilian soybean belt. In the Great Plains, the precipitation was in the form of snow, which should help insulate the dormant winter wheat crop from the brutal cold in the nation's midsection. The development was bearish for new-crop wheat contracts, those for delivery next spring. In Brazil, where it's late springtime, weekend rains brought relief to the soybean crop, which has been suffering through hot, dry conditions. Brazil is the world's second-largest soybean producer after the United States. Sub-zero temperatures in the Plains and Midwest helped support the wheat and soybean markets last week. Temperatures have warmed up slightly but are expected to plunge again before the weekend. At the close, wheat futures were 1\ cents lower to 2 cents higher with December at $4.15 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.34{ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with December at $1.42 a bushel; and soybeans were { cent to 2{ cents lower with January at $5.81{ a bushel.
